title: Want to run the world's top marathons? Good luck getting in
summary: Fueled by the rise of run clubs, social media and a growing interest in wellness, marathons have boomed in recent years, from Boston to New York City.
story: Most people will never run a marathon. Then there’s Adrian Decunto.
Decunto has not only run the six most popular marathons in the world, he’s done them all seven times each.

“If my body allowed me, I would run a marathon every week,” he said. His dedication may be singular, but his interest in running the world’s “Majors,” as these races are known, is part of a much larger movement.

Interest in running has never been higher, fueled by the rise of marathons, run clubs and social media influencers. That running boom has pushed demand for entry into the world’s premier races to unprecedented levels.

At the center of the frenzy is the Abbott World Marathon Majors, a circuit of seven of the sport’s most coveted races: London, New York, Berlin, Chicago, Tokyo, Boston and, most recently, Sydney. For many runners, completing all six of the original races has become the sport’s ultimate achievement, a feat that comes with a giant doughnut-shaped “six-star” medal and bragging rights for completing the equivalent of the “Amazing Race” for marathoners.
More than 22,000 people have completed the medal, according to Abbott, and hundreds of thousands more are chasing it.

“There’s just something so heightened about that experience and that accomplishment that is such a draw,” said Rob Dalto, a 37-year-old tech executive who ran each of the Majors the past two years and plans to do it again in 2025. “When you have an experience like you have at the New York City Marathon, it’s so much bigger than just yourself. You know you’re part of something much bigger.”

Dalto has become a World Marathon Majors influencer, building sizable followings on TikTok and Instagram through his journey of running the series every year. He’s just one of the obsessives and influencers who have made the Majors a burgeoning cultural phenomenon.

title: Trump heads to Asia with trade — and tensions with Xi — on the agenda
summary: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Donald Trump arrives in Southeast Asia on Sunday for his first visit to the continent since returning to office, a three-nation tour through Malaysia, Japan and South Korea that is expected to culminate in a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, as tensions between the world’s two biggest economies tick higher.“The first message is Trump the peacemaker.
story: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — President Donald Trump arrives in Southeast Asia on Sunday for his first visit to the continent since returning to office, a three-nation tour through Malaysia, Japan and South Korea that is expected to culminate in a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, as tensions between the world’s two biggest economies tick higher.

“The first message is Trump the peacemaker. The second is Trump the moneymaker,” said Victor Cha of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. “And then, of course, with the meeting with China, I think what everybody’s expecting is that there’s probably not going to be a big trade deal, but there will be an effort to de-escalate or put a pause on the situation.”

Trade is expected to dominate the week. Aboard Air Force One on Friday, Trump said he would subsidize U.S. farmers if he did not reach a deal with China, and that he planned to discuss the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war with Xi, saying he’d like to see China “help us out.”
The president also suggested he was angling for a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, even as the White House has said that no meeting is planned.
“You know, they don’t have a lot of telephone service,” Trump said, before urging reporters to “put out the word.”

In Kuala Lumpur, Trump is scheduled to meet with Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim before attending a working dinner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations leaders. Malaysia, this year’s ASEAN chair, has set “inclusivity and sustainability” as the summit theme.

The White House said Trump will also join a signing ceremony for a peace agreement between Cambodia and Thailand, whose deadly border conflict he has claimed credit for helping to resolve. During his first term, Trump attended the annual ASEAN summit only once.

Sandwiched between the summit in Kuala Lumpur and South Korea’s Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, Trump will pay an official visit to Japan, his fourth, for talks with the new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, and an audience with Japanese Emperor Naruhito.

Takaichi, a conservative protege of the late Shinzo Abe, has pledged to raise defense spending to 2% of GDP by March, two years ahead of schedule, a target likely to draw praise from Trump, who has pressed for allies to spend more. She has also raised the idea of revisiting the U.S.-Japan trade deal announced in July.

Trump and Abe forged a close personal relationship during his first term, before Abe’s assassination in 2022. Trump will also meet with business executives and visit American troops while in Japan, a country that hosts more U.S. service members than any other in the world.
In South Korea on Wednesday, Trump is slated to address business leaders at APEC, hold a bilateral meeting with the president and attend a leaders dinner that evening.

Topping the agenda at every stop is trade, with negotiators still ironing out the details of pacts with South Korea and Japan and taking steps toward agreements with China and Malaysia. U.S. and Chinese delegations are meeting in Malaysia over the weekend ahead of Trump’s arrival in Kuala Lumpur.

“It’s not the U.S. president coming to Asia to meet the multilateral schedule; it’s the U.S. president coming to Asia and then bending the multilateral schedule around his schedule,” said Cha, noting Trump is skipping the U.S.-ASEAN leaders meeting, the East Asia Summit and formal APEC sessions. Even so, Cha said, regional leaders are eager to engage.
“Everybody still wants to cut a deal with the U.S. president,” he said. “They all want tariff relief, and they will try to make a deal to achieve that.”

Central to the trip is Trump’s anticipated meeting with Xi in South Korea on Thursday, though Beijing has not yet confirmed the session. Top officials from the U.S. and China are sitting down in Malaysia on Saturday to find a way forward after Trump threatened new tariffs of 100% on Chinese goods and other trade limits starting on Nov. 1 in response to China’s expanded export controls on rare earth minerals and related technologies.

Trump has said he plans to raise the issue of fentanyl, accusing China of failing to curb the flow of precursor chemicals, and a senior administration official said China’s purchases of Russian oil will also be on the table. Trump said he also expects to discuss Taiwan.

“We have a lot to talk about with President Xi, and he has a lot to talk about with us,” Trump said Friday, adding he expects “a good meeting” even as he has intermittently threatened to call it off over trade frictions, including soybean purchases.
Both leaders want the optics and tactical aspect of this meeting to go well, a person familiar with the meeting planning said.

Analysts urged caution about what a leader-level encounter can deliver. “During Trump’s first term, high-level exchanges with China did not prevent him from later taking a harder line,” said Sun Chenghao, a fellow at Tsinghua University’s Center for International Security and Strategy. “So the symbolic value of summit diplomacy should not be overstated.”

Earlier this week, a senior administration official pushed back on speculation that Trump could reprise his 2019 encounter with North Korean’s Kim, when he made a surprise visit to the demilitarized zone that separates the two Koreas in an effort to revive nuclear talks that had collapsed. Trump said before leaving Washington on Friday that he “would like” to meet with Kim, but was unsure whether it would happen on this trip.
Kim says he will negotiate only if the U.S. recognizes North Korea as a nuclear power, and he has only further strengthened his weapons programs since Trump’s first term.
“I think they are sort of a nuclear power,” Trump said as he began his journey to Asia on Friday, perhaps paving the way for a possible meeting. “They’ve got a lot of nuclear weapons. I’ll say that.”

title: Tropical Storm Melissa, forecast to become major hurricane, barrels toward Jamaica and Cuba
summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is expected to intensify into a hurricane in the Caribbean on Saturday, bringing with it catastrophic flash flooding and potential landslides
story: Tropical Storm Melissa is expected to intensify into a hurricane in the Caribbean on Saturday, bringing with it catastrophic flash flooding and potential landslides.

The slow-moving storm is already responsible for the deaths of at least three people in Haiti. Meteorologists warn the storm could become a Category 4 hurricane, bringing major rainfall and destructive winds to the island of Jamaica.

A hurricane warning is in effect for Jamaica, and a hurricane watch is in place for the southwestern peninsula of Haiti, from the border with the Dominican Republic to Port-au-Prince. Watches could be in effect for portions of eastern Cuba later today, and total rainfall of 4 to 8 inches, with amounts up to 12 inches, is possible into Tuesday.

In an 11 a.m. ET update on Saturday, the National Hurricane Center said the slow-moving storm is crawling west-northwest at 1 mph. At the time of the update, the storm was about 155 miles southeast of Kingston, Jamaica's capital, and 235 miles southwest of Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital.
The NHC warned of “life-threatening and catastrophic flash flooding and landslides” through the weekend in Jamaica and southern Hispaniola, the island that comprises Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

The Haitian Civil Protection Agency said that two people died Thursday in a landslide in Fontamara, a suburb of Port-au-Prince. Earlier, the agency said a man in his 70s was killed by a falling tree in the southern coastal town of Marigot, while five people were injured in the Artibonite region.
Already, dozens of water supply systems are offline in the Dominican Republic, affecting more than 500,000 customers, with downed trees and traffic lights causing disruption.
In the U.S., strong to severe thunderstorms are expected to continue along the South and Gulf Coast this weekend.

The NHS declared a slight risk for severe weather impacting 14 million people across Texas, Louisiana and southwestern Mississippi where storms pose the threat of a few tornadoes, damaging wind gusts, and 2" + hail.
Although the primary risk on Sunday will be strong wind gusts, the NHS said it can't rule out a brief tornado.

At least 15 million people from Texas to Mississippi currently face Flood Alerts into Sunday afternoon. Rainfall totals through Sunday are expected to range from 2-4" inches with localized higher amounts possible.

title: DNA reveals the diseases that devastated Napoleon's doomed army
summary: When Napoleon marched into Russia in 1812, he brought with him the largest army Europe had ever seen.
story: When Napoleon marched into Russia in 1812, he brought with him the largest army Europe had ever seen. When he limped back out, he’d met his match — not in muskets or cannon fire, but in microbes.
Researchers who analyzed DNA from the teeth of soldiers who died during the retreat from Moscow say they have identified two diseases that devastated the emperor’s vaunted Grande Armée.

Ever since 1812, “people have thought that typhus was the most prevalent disease in the army,” said Nicolás Rascovan, the head of the microbial paleogenomics unit at the Institut Pasteur and an author of the study, published in the journal Current Biology.

Using a technique called shotgun sequencing, Rascovan and his team were able to analyze ancient DNA from the dental remains of 13 soldiers found near Vilnius, Lithuania, and identify two “previously undocumented pathogens.”

“We confirmed the presence of Salmonella enterica belonging to the Paratyphi C lineage,” he told NBC News, referring to the bacteria responsible for paratyphoid fever, as well as “Borrelia recurrentis, the bacteria responsible for relapsing fever,” which causes episodes of fever.
These diseases would have thrived where people “were under very poor sanitary conditions or hygiene,” he added.
The findings fit with historical descriptions of the symptoms experienced by soldiers in Napoleon’s army, such as fever and diarrhea, the researchers said in the study.
A “reasonable scenario” for the deaths would be a “combination of fatigue, cold, and several diseases, including paratyphoid fever and louse-borne relapsing fever,” they wrote.
“While not necessarily fatal, the louse-borne relapsing fever could significantly weaken an already exhausted individual,” they added.
Unlike a 2006 study that found traces of the bacteria that cause typhus or trench fever in four individuals among a group of 35, the team found no traces of those diseases.

But Rascovan said that while the earlier study was limited by the technology of the time, its results remained valid and, coupled with the new findings, gave a better picture of the conditions that laid waste to Napoleon’s army.
“Finding four different pathogens in such a number of individuals, it really shows that there were a high prevalence of infectious diseases of all kinds,” he said.
By the time Napoleon’s troops had retreated, an estimated 300,000 men had died. Even an emperor, it seems, can’t outmarch a microbe.

title: Mindy Kaling Reveals She Turned Down Date Set up from Reese Witherspoon
summary: Mindy Kaling opened up about her dating life and revealed there was once a time when her friend Reese Witherspoon tried to set her up on a date.
story: Mindy Kaling is opening up about her dating life.

While appearing on the Oct. 21 episode of the "One Nightstand" podcast, the single mom of three revealed there was once a time when her "Wrinkle in Time" co-star Reese Witherspoon tried to set her up on a date.

“Pretty recently, Reese Witherspoon wanted to set me up with somebody and I didn’t even look to see who it was,” she said. “I didn’t laugh in her face because I love her and I love that she was thinking of me in that way, but I just thought, ‘It’s not time.’”

"But I laughed at the idea of doing my hair and putting on makeup and getting out there. Like, I have three kids under the age of 7, so for me to want to leave them, especially when I travel for work a lot, just, you know," she added.
Though Kaling said that she doesn't look forward to dating, she said that she still does "love romance" and is not "anti-men."
Earlier in the interview, she elaborated on her dating life and  explained why she's happy being single.

“When I was younger, I was yearning for professional success and personal success and both weighed on me equally,” she shared. “Now that I have professional success, it’s hard to muster up the energy. Both were sort of quenched when one was fulfilled.”

“When I was younger, I was like, ‘If I don’t have a date on Saturday night, I’m a loser. I failed.' And now, as you get older and smarter, you’re like, ‘Well, I don’t care about that. And no one cares if I do either,'" she added.

Kaling noted that she believes one has to be "recklessly optimistic" when they date as an older person. She explained that she's "set" in her ways and not as "malleable" as she was when she was younger.
"I'm happy with my three kids and with my messed up way of thinking about relationships," she said. "It's fine for me being single."

title: Is Lily Allen's New Album About Ex David Harbour? What She Reveals in Her Songs
summary: Lily Allen is lashing out at an unfaithful former partner on her scathing new album, “West End Girl,” out Oct.
story: Lily Allen is lashing out at an unfaithful former partner on her scathing new album, “West End Girl,” out Oct. 24.

Following reports last year that the British singer, 40, had separated from “Stranger Things” star David Harbour, 50, People reported in February that the two had officially called it quits after four years of marriage.

Now, on “West End Girl,” her first album in more than seven years, Allen chronicles a relationship’s bitter breakdown caused by a partner’s cheating. Across 14 mostly downtempo tracks, Allen weaves together the story of a partner who led a “double life” and violated an “open” marriage code.
On the somber “Sleepwalking,” Allen’s protagonist describes being convinced by her partner that their problems are her fault.
“‘Why aren’t we f-----, baby?’ / Yeah, that’s what you said,” she  sings. “But you let me think it was me in my head / And nothing to do with them girls in your bed.”

Allen is more forceful on the blistering “P---- Palace,” referring to the person who inspired the biting track as a “sex addict.” She describes finding a shopping bag filled with various “sex toys” that the man she is calling out used while he lived a “double life.”
The Grammy nominee doesn’t shy away from naming names in some cases. On “Tennis,” she describes how an ex nervously “grabbed” his phone back after showing her an Instagram photo.
“If it was just sex I wouldn’t be jealous,” she sings in the chorus, adding, “You won’t play with me and who the f--- is Madeline?”

The mystery woman pops up again in a separate song Allen titles “Madeline.” She sings directly to her partner’s lover on the heartbreaking track, asking how long their affair has been happening. She explains to Madeline how her ex broke the rules of their “arrangement,” which allowed him to sleep with other partners as long as he paid for the sex and the women were “strangers.”
“But you’re not a stranger, Madeline,” she sings.

Allen and Harbour tied the knot in September 2020 at the Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, and he shared photos from their special day on Instagram. The two met the year prior on the celebrity dating app Raya, according to People.
Harbour was the stepfather of Allen’s two daughters, Ethel Mary, who turns 14 in November, and Marnie Rose, 12. Allen shares both children with ex-husband Sam Cooper.
In January 2025, without naming Harbour, Allen revealed on her BBC podcast “Miss Me?” that she was trying “to be present” for her daughters despite “spiraling” while going through a “tough period.”
“We are a support network for each other and encourage each other to talk about our feelings but I think the main thing is telling them we’re going to get through it and be fine,” she said.

title: How TODAY Anchors Really Feel About Cooking Segments: Craig’s Face Says It All
summary: Craig Melvin, Shenielle Jones and Dylan Dreyer talk about how they feel about the show's cooking segments during the TODAY Fan Fest event Taste of TODAY.
story: Craig Melvin wears his heart on his sleeve — and his taste buds on his face.
Asked if he can name the best thing he’s ever eaten during a TODAY Food segment, Craig visibly flips through his Rolodex of memories, finally shaking his head.
“I can’t answer that question because every month or two, I’m like, ‘Oh, my God,’” he says, his eyes lighting up.
He’s getting ready to guide an audience through a cooking demo at the TODAY Fan Fest event Taste of TODAY, hosted at Platform by the James Beard Foundation.
Also in attendance, a slew of super-fans watch TODAY Food segments happen in real life, mingle with the anchors and world-class chefs, and enjoy bites from the demos.

“We had some Korean fried chicken this morning; she’s here tonight,” Craig says of chef Judy Joo and her recipe. “I was like, ‘Oh, my God, this is the most amazing Korean fried chicken I’ve ever had.’”
Get The Recipe

Craig adds that earlier in the week, chef Brian Lewis prepared his Herbed Pork Roast during the 3rd Hour, and he thought the same thing: “Oh, my God, this is the best pork I’ve ever had,” he remembers.
Sheinelle Jones has a similar reaction to another one of Lewis’ dishes that day: the Roasted Beet and Burrata Salad.
“It was like a beet salad, but it’s not just any beet salad,” she says, waving her hands in the air, emphatically. “It had fennel and pistachio. It was, like, amazing.”

Alongside anchors Savannah Guthrie, Jenna Bush Hager and Dylan Dreyer, three chefs make their dishes from the “TODAY Loves Food” cookbook. While sampling those foods, attendees are also being served wine, beer and cocktails like Savannah’s Savanita, provided by Diageo, Rockaway Brewing Company and Brooklyn Winery.

On the menu tonight: Ayesha Nurdjaja’s Chicken Shawarma with White Sauce, David Rose’s Ancho Grilled Skirt Steak with Chipotle Chimichurri and Katie Lee Biegel’s Chopped Dill Pickle Salad, all  prepared live for the audience by each chef.
Craig says his favorite thing about food segments is the expertise on display.

“It’s just the quality of food,” he says, especially from culinary stars like Siri Daly, Edy Massih and Priyanka Naik, who are all in attendance. “The untold part of the TODAY Food story is the TODAY Food team, and they just do a remarkable job.”
He enjoys most things he eats on the show, but every now and again, he tries a dish that’s not his thing — and his face makes that clear.
“I can’t hide it,” Craig admits.
“My mother has said the same thing. But, listen, I’ll try anything,” he says, adding that not everything is for everyone. “I think I’ve gotten better.”
Sheinelle says she’s taken home food from the show that she really enjoyed, but it’s not always a hit with her kids.
“My kids don’t like their food to touch, so they’re still in the like, ‘We like chicken, we like potatoes,’ so sometimes I’ll bring something home, and they’re like, ‘I’m not sure.”
But the easiest way to tell if an anchor enjoyed the dish is to take a look at their plate at the end of the segment. If it’s empty, it was a hit.
“I’m called out on a lot on how much food I’m eating,” Dylan says during the event’s opening remarks. “When you’re surrounded by the best-of-the best chefs, you want to taste their food.
“And then my mom’s texting me after, ‘Was that really as good as you made it sound? Should I try that recipe?’ and I say, ‘Yes, you have to try that recipe.’”

title: Rita Moreno Flirts with Bad Bunny at the 2025 Latin Billboards
summary: Rita Moreno had a flirtatious moment with Bad Bunny at the 2025 Latin Billboard Music Awards when she presented him with his accolade on stage.
story: Bad Bunny and Rita Moreno had a moment at the 2025 Latin Billboard Music Awards.
The "West Side Story" actor and singer made a flirtatious comment toward the rapper when she presented him with the award for Top Latin Artist of the 21st Century.
Moreno, who made a surprise appearance at the Oct. 23 event, started off her speech by calling the musician attractive.
"How are you?" she said while looking at Bad Bunny in the crowd in Spanish, according to a translation by TODAY. Then she joked: "You are looking good ... all over!"
The 93-year-old then spoke about her Hollywood career and the barriers she faced as a Puerto Rican-born artist.

"Opportunities were few, almost nonexistent. And every step forward was a victory," she said. "Today, I see an artist who brings to the whole world that same strength, that same passion that helped me never to give up."
"I am very deeply moved from my heart, Benito, to present you the Billboard Latin Artist of the 21st Century Award," she added to a cheering crowd.
After the two shared a hug and a quick dance, Bad Bunny — who, like Moreno, is Puerto Rican — gave her a shout-out on stage.
"Thank you very much. And same to you!" he said. "Thank you for those words, for me to receive this award from your hands ... I respect you a lot, I admire you a lot. And ... wow."

"Every time I hear other artists express themselves that way about me, it gives me the confidence that being myself and doing things with my heart will always be a great decision," he added. "Because that is the only thing I have done from day one. I have been gradually finding myself, little by little discovering who I am and what I represent."

Bad Bunny said that he's receiving his award with "pride" because he knows how "hard" he worked in his career. He then dedicated his trophy to other artists who are trying to get further in their careers.

“This award is also for you, because I will always identify with young people and with the new artists who are growing and dreaming,” he said. “I will always identify with those artists, because I consider myself still a young person who continues to dream with many goals and many things still to do.”
“I don’t accept this (award) with arrogance; I accept it with great humility. I will continue being the same. I love you all. Thank you,” he concluded.
After wrapping up his record-breaking Puerto Rico residency, Bad Bunny was announced as the performer for Super Bowl LX in September.

title: What Happens At the End of ‘Regretting You’? The Big Twist, Explained
summary: How does "Regretting You" end? What to know about the big family secret at the center of the new Colleen Hoover film.
story: After the official trailer for "Regretting You" dropped, viewers likely had more questions than answers when it comes to the Colleen Hoover story's premise.
The second book by Hoover to be adapted for the big screen, "Regretting You" follows 17-year-old Clara Grant (Mckenna Grace) and her mother, Morgan (Allison Williams), in the aftermath of tragedy.

Clara is the daughter of Morgan and Chris Grant (Scott Eastwood), who had her when they were still in high school. Morgan's sister, Jenny, is newly engaged to her former high-school sweetheart Jonah (Dave Franco) after they reconnected, had a one-night-stand and welcomed a baby boy named Elijah.

But the family's close dynamic is shattered when Chris and Jenny are killed in a car accident together, leaving Morgan and Jonah to reckon with why they were together in the first place. Meanwhile Clara, heartbroken by the death of her father and aunt, embarks on a relationship with Miller (Mason Thames), a boy from her school.
In true Hoover fashion, "Regretting You," which comes just over a year after her first movie adaptation, "It Ends with Us," takes viewers through twists, turns and plenty of swoonworthy romance.
The movie hit theaters Oct. 24. After the credits roll, here's your guide to any lingering questions.
🚨🚨🚨Warning: Major spoilers ahead for the end of "Regretting You."
What Was Going on Between Chris and Jenny?
Chris, Clara's father and husband to Morgan, and Jenny, Morgan's sister who was engaged to Jonah, were having an affair at the time of their death.
It is revealed Chris was driving Jenny's car before the accident, even though their respective partners thought they were both at work.
After the accident, Morgan and Jonah track down the location of Chris's car and find it parked outside of a hotel.
Jonah goes inside and finds Jenny's bag in a hotel room, which was packed with lingerie. This confirms to Morgan that her husband and sister had been having an affair and sends her into a fury.

Later in the film, Jonah finds a stack of letters Jenny had written to Chris in an old toolbox. Morgan and Jonah realize the letters are quite dated, confirming the affair had been going on for a while.
Who Is Elijah's Father?
The revelation of the affair calls into question the paternity of Jenny's 1-year-old son, Elijah.
After the accident, Jonah shows up to Morgan's house and starts to bang on the front door. He announces that Elijah "has his smile," referring to Chris.
Although never explicitly confirmed, it is implied for the rest of the film that Elijah is actually Chris' biological child.

After the initial shock of discovering that Elijah is not his child, Jonah leaves Elijah in the care of Morgan. Jonah does not see Elijah for a few days, until Clara — whom Morgan has intentionally kept in the dark about her father and aunt's affair — shows up to his house and tells him to go and get his child back.

Jonah realizes that even if he is not Elijah's biological father, he loves him and wants to raise him as his son. Jonah runs to Morgan's house and apologizes for leaving Elijah and promises to never leave again.

As Morgan supports Jonah with Elijah, their close friendship from high school resumes and gradually turns romantic. Eventually, it's revealed that when they were teenagers, Jonah had asked Morgan if "they had it wrong," implying he thought he and Morgan were supposed to be together, instead of Morgan and Chris, and Jenny and Jonah.
Does Clara Find out About the Affair?

One of the first scenes of the movie establishes the close relationship between Clara and her aunt Jenny. While running late for family dinner, Clara calls Jenny to tell her a story about Miller, a boy from school who later becomes her boyfriend. She ends the call by saying, "Don't tell my mom."
Their mother-daughter relationship is also strained by Clara’s dreams of studying acting, which Morgan doesn’t believe is a responsible choice.
So when Morgan uncovers the affair, she tells Jonah that Clara can never find out about it, as she does not want to ruin Clara's memories of her dad and aunt.

When Clara arrives home one evening and walks in on Morgan and Jonah sharing their first kiss, she storms into her room upset. Unaware of their shared history, Clara assumes that her mom and her aunt's fiancé had moved on.

Clara avoids her mother for a few days, until one morning when Morgan helps her overcome a hangover. As they are sitting at the kitchen table, Morgan finally reveals to Clara that Chris and Jenny had been having an affair.
How Does 'Regretting You' End?
After learning the truth, Clara is able to more healthily pursue her relationship with Miller, and Morgan finally begins a long-awaited relationship with Jonah.
The final scene of the film sees Clara returning home from acting rehearsal to find her family, friends and now boyfriend Miller in front of a projector screen.
Jonah and Morgan sit on a coach together, with baby Elijah laying next to them. The two share a kiss and watch as Miller begins a speech.
Miller announces he has been accepted off the waitlist to a film school, the same school Clara plans to attend for their acting program the next year.

Miller and Clara are overjoyed to be attending the same college, and he plays a short film that he made for Clara. In the film, Miller shows videos of him and Clara from the past year, and he asks Clara to be his date to prom.

After the film, Morgan pulls Clara aside to say she supports her dream to study acting in college, despite her initial doubts. Morgan tells Clara she has an incredible talent, and that she will be able to succeed. The mother and daughter finally embrace.

title: Miss USA Contestant Is First With Total Hair Loss from Alopecia: 'I'm Still Me'
summary: Miss USA contestant Mary Sickler was diagnosed with alopecia universalis and lost all hair. The model the first to compete without hair in the beauty pageant.
story: Miss USA contestant Mary Sickler calls it the proudest moment of her life. After hiding her complete hair loss from alopecia for months, she decided to very publicly take off her wig during the competition.
Sickler wore a beaded silver head covering to match her sparkly evening gown for a preliminary round in Reno, Nevada, on Wednesday, Oct. 22.
She’s the first contestant to walk the Miss USA stage without hair, the pageant confirms. It was also the first time she has ever appeared without a wig in front of judges and an audience.
“It was something that I never imagined doing,” Sickler, 22, who lives in Las Vegas and is competing as Miss Nevada, tells TODAY.com.
“I was extremely nervous before walking out on stage. And the second I walked off, I actually started crying from all the emotions.”
It’s been a long journey from feeling “ugly” after her alopecia diagnosis to now, when she says she’s “never felt more beautiful.” The winner of Miss USA will be announced on Friday, Oct. 24.

Sickler started losing her hair less than a year ago. In December 2024, she found a circular bald spot on the top of her head, but thought she had just pulled her hair out while doing a slicked-back ponytail.
When more bald patches appeared, she was diagnosed with alopecia areata. But the patchy hair loss soon progressed even more, and Sickler started losing eyebrows, eyelashes, and leg and arm hair.
The final diagnosis: alopecia universalis, or total hair loss on the scalp and all over the body.
She shaved the last 50 remaining hairs on her head in July.
‘Never Felt Uglier’
Sickler, who’s been competing in beauty pageants since she was a child, was devastated. She was also worried about her career as a full-time working model signed to a top agency in New York.
Sickler wondered: How could she work without any hair? So she decided to keep her hair loss a secret.
“I was afraid people would look at me differently. I mean, I was always known to have my hair big and glam in the pageant world and in everyday life,” she says.
“I didn't want people to think of me less than. I didn't want people to think that I was sick.”
There was also the emotional toll of losing hair, which she calls a big part of her identity.
“I had never felt uglier in my entire life. I had never looked in the mirror and not recognized who I was,” Sickler recalls.

“You look in the mirror, you have no eyebrows, you have no lashes, you have 20% of your hair, you don't even feel like the same girl. But I think the biggest thing that I had to realize was with hair or without hair, I was still Mary Sickler. I was still the hardworking, determined, courageous girl that I was with hair or without.”
What Is Alopecia?
Alopecia is an autoimmune condition that happens when the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys healthy hair follicles, according to the National Library of Medicine.
About 700,000 Americans have some form of the skin disease, according to the National Alopecia Areata Foundation. It's not known what triggers it.
About 20% of patients have at least one family member with alopecia, it notes. But Sickler has no family history so she called her diagnosis a “complete shock.”
There are several types of the condition: Alopecia areata means patchy hair loss; alopecia totalis is complete scalp hair loss; and alopecia universalis means hair on the entire body is affected.
Another woman diagnosed with alopecia universalis as a child previously told TODAY.com people don’t realize what an emotional roller coaster the condition is.

“Superman” and “Barry” actor Anthony Carrigan told TODAY having alopecia “used to be the thing that I had so much shame over,” but now calls it his superpower. “I can’t think of myself with hair,” he said on the show in July.
Opening Up About Hair Loss
Sickler went public with her condition on Instagram in September, noting she didn't want to keep hiding and found courage after winning the Miss Nevada competition.
She believes it happened for a reason — a chance to share her story, offer hope and help others.

“I knew that I would be touching so many women and men out there because I truly believe this is not just about hair loss. This is about any person who has gone through a trial, any person pursuing a dream who thought they couldn't do it,” Sickler says.
“People have said, ‘I don't have alopecia, but I feel like I don't fit in and I'm so proud of you.’ And that's why I did it. I did that for those people.”
Sickler hopes to continue modeling and represent women who don't have hair. Opening up has been a relief.
"I felt this calling that there was a reason why I am at Miss USA without any hair," she says.

title: Who Is in the Cast of 'Married at First Sight' Season 19?
summary: Who is in the Cast of "Married at First Sight" Season 19. Find out who the couples are for the 2025 season of the dating reality show.
story: "Married at First Sight" has a brand new home and cast.
The reality dating series, which tasks participants with saying "I do" the first time they meet, is now a Peacock original series after previously airing on FYI and Lifetime.

Season 19 kicked off on Oct. 23 with episodes 1 - 4 and introduced viewers to 10 Texas singles who were about to meet their spouses at the altar. From there, the newly-married couples began to work with a team of experts to learn the tools they'll need for a lasting marriage.
At the end of the eight-week experiment, all five couples will need to decide if they're going to stay married or break up.
Ready to tune in for all the action? Get to know the cast below and find out when all the episodes drop.
How to Watch 'Married at First Sight'
Season 19 of “Married at First Sight” will stream on Peacock. It will include 13 episodes and a reunion. Here’s the schedule:
Oct. 23: Episodes 1 - 4  Oct. 30: Episodes 5 - 7  Nov. 6: Episodes 8 - 10  Nov. 13: Episodes 11 - 12  Nov. 20: Finale and reunion
Oct. 23: Episodes 1 - 4
Oct. 30: Episodes 5 - 7
Nov. 6: Episodes 8 - 10
Nov. 13: Episodes 11 - 12
Nov. 20: Finale and reunion
Meet the Season 19 'Married at First Sight' Couples:
Josh and Jalyn

Josh, a 31-year-old contractor, is seeking the “steady family life” he missed while growing up and is “ready for marriage” now that he’s in a “secure, emotionally mature phase of life,” according to his bio.
“He believes this bold leap of faith, with the help of the experts, could lead to his perfect partner,” his bio reads.

Jalyn is a 27-year-old realtor who took time off from dating to prioritize her career and herself after “a turbulent experience with dating,” according to her bio. Going into the “Married at First Sight” experiment, Jalyn is “thriving professionally and secure in who she is” and hopes it’s “the perfect way to find true love, once and for all.”
Derrek and Meghann

Derrek is a 38-year-old chief automator who is tired of the “surface-level connections” he’s made while living and dating all around the world, according to his bio. The health and wellness entrepreneur is looking for “an equal” who shares his passion for balance and longevity.

Meghann, a 37-year-old realtor, has been single for seven years and has a hard time balancing life and work. While starring on “Married at First Sight,” she’s “ready to trust the experts in finding her a partner in life and love,” according to her bio.
Pat and Rhonda

Pat is a 59-year-old space operations consultant who was previously married for 30 years and has adult children. Although he’s dated since his divorce, Pat hasn’t felt a “special spark” with anyone. As he heads into the “Married at First Sight” experience, Pat is ready to tap into his “adventurous spirit and open heart” as he looks for love.

Rhonda, a 63-year-old performance marketing executive, describes herself as a “true romantic at heart” in her bio. She’s been married twice and has four children. Looking ahead, Rhonda is ready to ditch the dating apps and “put her trust in this unique matchmaking process.”
Chad and Belynda
Chad is a 54-year-old real estate executive who has been divorced three times. Now that he’s been single for three years, Chad is ready to find love once again.

Belynda is a 47-year-old esthetic consultant who has “so much love to give,” according to her bio. She’s learned a lot from her parents’ divorce and her own and is “open to the experts’ guidance” as she embarks on the “Married at First Sight” journey.
Will and Brittany

Will is a 30-year-old consultant who is eager to get married after spending many years focused on his career. In the past, he “hasn’t been the best at choosing partners,” per his bio, but he’s hopeful that he can find a “lifelong match” while appearing on the show.

Brittany, a 29-year-old strategic HR business partner, has had many relationships that only last a few months. She’s always “dreamed of being a wife for as long as she can remember.” Ready for “something deeper,” Brittany sees this as a “second chance” after previously applying for the show and not being selected.

title: 'Nobody Wants This' Stars Explain Ending of Season 2 and What's Next
summary: What happens at the end of "Nobody Wants This" Season 2? Kristin Bell, Justine Lupe and more explain the ending of season two and what's next for Noah and Joanne.
story: Spoilers ahead for Season 2 of “Nobody Wants This.”
Season 1 of “Nobody Wants This” left viewers with high expectations (especially after that epic kiss), and the sophomore season certainly delivered.

After hitting Netflix on Oct. 23, Season 2 of the endearing romantic comedy revisited the central issue in Joanne (Kristen Bell) and Noah's (Adam Brody) relationship: Will she or won't she convert to Judaism?
"Nobody Wants This," which is based on writer and creator Erin Foster’s real life and love story, follows agnostic podcaster Joanne and her rabbi boyfriend, Noah.

In the Season 1 finale, Joanne decides to convert to Judaism for Noah after realizing how important his faith is to him. She soon changes her mind and decides she needs to think it through more. Their relationship seemed to be over, but Noah then decides he would accept Joanne as she is even if she couldn't convert.

Season 2 follows the couple as they navigate the topic of conversion and consider taking their relationship to the next level. How does it all end? We're recapping the highlights of the Season 2 finale.
Joanne and Noah Are at Odds Over Her Living Situation

When Joanne unexpectedly gets evicted from her home, she’s eager to figure out where she should live next. While researching real estate online in Episode 9, she sees a three-bedroom apartment and mentions it to Noah. He asks what she’s going to do with three bedrooms and she says she’s “thinking ahead.”

“Yeah, I mean obviously in a perfect world we’d just move in together. But it’s all about timing. Don’t worry, though, you’re gonna find a place you love so much you’re never gonna want to leave,” he replies.
Later on, Noah explains to his brother Sasha (Timothy Simons) that he doesn’t think living with Joanne just yet is a “good idea.”

During a triple date with Morgan (Justine Lupe), Andy (Arian Moayed), Sasha and Esther (Jackie Tohn), Joanne pushes the issue while they play a card game and Noah gets the following question on his turn: “What was a difficult decision you made recently?”

At first, Noah cites his decision to leave his old temple, but Joanne pushes him then Morgan brings up the topic of moving in together. Noah grows frustrated and says, “Because it wasn’t a difficult decision.”
Later, Noah and Joanne discuss the matter in private and Joanne expresses her frustration with her boyfriend.

“You seem to have one foot on the gas and one foot on the break and, honestly, it’s reminding me of my previous relationships. Am I not reading the signs here properly? ‘Cause I assumed that it was a difficult decision because I thought you wanted a future with me,” she says.
Noah reassures Joanne that he does “want that” and she asks why they can’t move in together.

“Because we haven’t answered the question of conversion yet. Ok? And I am scared. I am scared that if we move in together now then that’ll be it and we will never deal with the question of conversion because we won’t have to and I will be unhappy and maybe even resentful,” he says.
Joanne says she’s “inching towards conversion” but “can’t guarantee it.”
“If you can't move in with me as I am now, I don’t see how we do move forward,” she says.
Morgan Calls Off Her Wedding to Andy
After a whirlwind romance with her former therapist, Dr. Andy, Morgan calls off their engagement in the season finale.
While attending her engagement party, Morgan opens up to Joanne and confesses that she's not as into Andy as she thought she was.
“He weaponizes things that I said to him in therapy when I thought that I was opening up in a safe space,” Morgan explains while reflecting on her relationship frustrations.
Morgan asks her sister to push her to break up with him. Joanne proceeds to tell Morgan a few stories about Andy that give her “the ick” and she encourages Morgan to break up with him immediately.

When Morgan attempts to break things off, Andy convinces her to stay together. Joanne, who is dealing with her own relationship drama with Noah, then reminds Morgan that she's lucky she's with someone who wants to take their relationship to the next level.

Joanne speaks with her parents about Morgan’s conundrum and their mother Lynn (Stephanie Faracy) is inspired to give Morgan a pep talk. Lynn reminds her that she deserves “an equal partnership” and “someone who holds you accountable but sees the best in you.”
Morgan breaks up with Andy once and for all and explains why.

“You made me feel like I was special, like you saw all the darkest parts of me and you found them endearing. And I don’t know, it made me ignore things that I should’ve paid attention to. And if I’m being really honest with myself, Joanne’s relationship made me rush into this with you and I wanted to catch up with her. But that’s not how I want to live my life,” she said.
In an interview with TODAY.com, Lupe expresses her hopes for a Season 3 and says she’d love to explore how her character grows while navigating this breakup.
“I’m excited to see her dive into being an independent woman in the world and seeing what she runs into because she’s gonna be chaotic no matter what,” she says.
Esther Tells Sasha She Needs Space

Throughout the season, Esther and Sasha's relationship has been a bit off as they've gone from lovey-dovey to distant and aloof. In the season finale, their marital issues come to a head when Esther admits that she can sense that something is off.
While attending Morgan's engagement party, Esther says their marriage is "not working." Sasha agrees that his wife hasn't been herself lately.
“So I am going to stay out of your way,” he says. “I’ve been trying to figure this out for us, or for you, reigniting the spark, as they say.”
Esther tells her husband he’s the “greatest guy” and “the best dad” then thanks him for all that he’s done to support her.

“I know how hard you’ve tried, I do, but it’s not working. It’s not working and I don’t know why. But what I do know is that it’s me right now and I can’t fix it while we’re together. I can’t believe I just said that,” she says.
“That makes two of us,” Sasha says.
While talking with Morgan later in the episode, Sasha makes it clear that he’s willing to wait for his wife.

“I mean, if she thinks that she can just go out there and see what life is like on the other side without me and I’ll just wait and take her back, she’s absolutely right. I mean, if this is for life, I’ve got to ride with her,” he says.

In an interview with TODAY.com, Tohn reflects on her character’s journey throughout the series thus far. The actor said Esther realizes in Season 1 that “everyone else is having a good time” and she wasn’t.

“I think in Season 2, her journey is a real self-discovery journey. ‘Are these the decisions I would’ve made if we didn’t just get pregnant with Miriam (Shiloh Bearman)?’ And now I’ve just been sort of on this high speed train of, ‘This is how you live life if your mother-in-law’s a nag, but you deal with her. And this and that and the other. And we have this daughter and she’s gonna have the bat mitzvah and the whole thing,’” she explains.
In Season 2, Tohn says Esther is “taking a breath” and reflecting on her life decisions while also admitting that she “wants to have more fun.”
Noah and Joanne Break Up — Then Get Back Together

You can cut the tension with a knife when Noah and Joanne arrive at Morgan's engagement party. They still can't see eye-to-eye on Joanne's living situation and neither of them seems willing to budge. For Morgan's sake, they agree to fake it and pretend that nothing's wrong during the party.
When Noah suggests that they give themselves six months “to enjoy each other and take the pressure off” and not talk about conversion, Joanne is offended and says, “I’m tired of waiting.”
While talking with Sasha, Noah realizes that relationships shouldn’t be this hard and he seeks out Joanne, seemingly ready to break things off.

“There are 100 different ways I could convince you to be with me right now but I’m not going to do that. Nothing good happens when it’s forced. I don’t want to be the person who’s asking you to be someone different. We can’t start our life that way. You would wake up in 20 years and hate me,” he says.
Joanne isn’t sure what Noah is trying to say and asks if he’s “just giving up.”
“It’s not giving up. It’s accepting the truth of our situation,” he replies.
“Is this happening right now? Are we breaking up right now?" she asks.
“I don’t know what other choice we have. I love you but we can’t keep doing this. It’s too hard,” he says.
When Joanne runs into Esther later, she gets the pep talk she needs to move forward in her relationship when Esther reminds her that she’s “basically Jewish” already.

“I feel like you have this idea of being Jewish that’s so much more complicated than it really is. You feel Jewish to me. You’re warm, cozy, you always want to chat about everything. You’d be a pretty good get for us,” Esther says.

Fresh off a tough conversation with Sasha, Esther doubles down on her advice to Joanne, saying, “I don’t really know what you’re waiting for. Whether it’s a sign or the waters to part or what. But the whole thing is just a feeling and enjoying all those little things is the feeling.”
In that moment, Joanne seems to finally get clarity.
“With or without Noah, you’re Jewish,” Esther says.
Joanne runs out to be with Noah at the same time he does. At first, they miss each other but then come face-to-face.
“None of it matters. You are my soulmate. I don’t care if you’re Jewish. I don’t care if you’re not Jewish. I choose you every time,” Noah says.
“Well, you’re in luck,” Joanne replies and they kiss.
In an interview with TODAY.com, Bell reflects on what was going on in Joanne's head as she spoke with Esther.

“Sometimes all you need is someone in your life to point out a different framework, a different pair of glasses that you can look through, and all of a sudden, everything becomes clear,” she said. “Prior to that scene, Joanne was seeing conversion or Judaism as something so different from what she was and so far away from what she could attain.”
After talking with Esther, Joanne was able to see “that she’s a lot closer to who she wants to be and what she wants than she previously thought.”

title: Scottish Singer Susan Boyle Debuts Chic New Blond Look. See the Pic
summary: Scottish singer Susan Boyle turned heads with her glamorous new blond look.
story: Scottish singer Susan Boyle is turning heads with her glamorous new look.

The former "Britain's Got Talent" star, 64, debuted chic blond hair that was cut into a sleek bob when she walked the red carpet at the 2025 Pride of Britain Awards at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London on Oct. 20.
Boyle wore a black-and-white patterned dress and wrapped herself in a black shawl. She completed her look with a black clutch, pearl necklace and several eye-catching bracelets on her wrists.
The annual Pride of Britain Awards honor British citizens for acts of courage, kindness and resilience.
Boyle shared several pics from the event on Instagram. In her caption, she wrote that it was "an honor to celebrate so many truly inspiring people."
“A night full of pride, joy, and admiration for some incredible heroes," she added.
Boyle's fans raved about her new look in the comments of her post.
"You look beautiful and your hair looks fab too," one wrote.
"Looking absolutely gorgeous..and such a beautiful outfit," added another.

The singer shot to stardom in 2009 as a contestant on Season 3 of "Britain's Got Talent" when she performed a stunning rendition of “I Dreamed a Dream” from “Les Misérables" during the show's audition rounds.
Boyle, who finished as a runner-up on the show, went on to release several hit solo albums.
During a surprise return visit to “Britain’s Got Talent” in June 2023, Boyle joined the West End cast of “Les Misérables” to perform “I Dreamed A Dream” again.
During her appearance, Boyle revealed she'd suffered a stroke in April 2022, making her return to the show's stage that much more emotional.
“I have fought like crazy to get back on stage,” Boyle announced. “And I have done it.”

title: Friends Go Viral for Awkward Photo Shoot Dressed as Dwayne Johnson in the ‘90s
summary: Two best friends tapped into '90s photo nostalgia by doing an awkward photo shoot dressed as Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson in a now viral video.
story: Two best friends have taken the awkward photo shoot trend to a whole new level in a now-viral TikTok channeling Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, '90s style.

Decade-long friends Elliot Richards and Travis Gregory noticed the once-common tradition resurfacing as a social media sensation, with people tapping into nostalgia by doing elaborate photo sessions with friends and family at professional studios, such as JCPenney.
“I’ve always been a huge fan of taking those kind of funny photos,” Gregory tells TODAY.com. “People like them, you know, it shows a different side of you. It’s great.”
Richards says they knew they had to partake in it.
“So I was like, ‘We got to do it. We got to try,’” Richards recalls.
Richards researched “JCPenny candid photos” on Google Maps, which led him to Mona Lisa Photography in Sterling, Virginia. He booked an appointment with the owner, Hamza Yildirim, for the next day.
When brainstorming what they should wear for the shoot, Gregory immediately thought of Johnson.
“The first thing that came to my mind was The Rock,” Gregory shares, saying that he's a "huge" fan of the "greatest actor of all time."

He recalls thinking about an iconic look of Johnson's from the '90s, where the famed wrestler rocks a black long-sleeved turtleneck and a silver chain around his neck, paired with jeans, a black belt and a fanny pack.
"Everybody knows the photo so perfect, let’s get the outfit," Gregory recounts.
Johnson recreated the look in 2017, when he shared a side-by-side post alongside the original outfit. In the caption, he reflected on the hardships he endured to get where he is now.

"If you’re going thru your own tough times “used mattress” stage, do your best to have faith things’ll get better and always be willing to outwork your competition because you never know where life is gonna take you," Johnson wrote at the time.
Gregory and Richards perfectly replicated Johnson’s outfit, and even posed with a similar lean and grip on their fanny packs.

During the hour-long photo shoot, Gregory’s wife, Sheryn Reid, captured content and helped direct their poses. She was the one who edited and uploaded the video on TikTok, sharing behind-the-scenes footage and the professional photos as a joke. But the response proved that it was far more than that.
The clip, which was shared on Sept. 16, now has over 8 million views and over 956,000 likes.
“I didn’t believe it at first,” Richards says of the viral reaction.
“It kind of skyrocketed it ... it was kind of unreal that it happened,” Gregory adds.
But has Johnson himself seen the tribute?
As far as the best friend duo knows, not yet, Gregory says it would be “sweet” if Johnson saw did see their video on social media.
Gregory, Richards and Reid called Yildirim after the video went viral.
“As soon as they call me, my hair just goes up ... I don’t know what to say,” Yildirim says.
The best friends have done another throwback photo shoot since then in bright-colored '90s jumpsuits, which they shared in a TikTok video on Sept. 24.
“I like the jumpsuit look like the old school, like Russian mafia, ‘Goofy,’ look,” Richards said. “So we did both, and people seem to like the first one more, at least for now.”
Their second attempt still brought in over 877,000 views — and it might be just the beginning of their photo shoot era.
“It’s fun to do and it seems like people like it,” Richards said. “We do it for ourselves first and foremost. There was no intention of ‘we’re going to be viral'.”

title: Jelly Roll Says He Previously Cheated on Wife Bunnie XO: 'I Don't Talk About This Publicly'
summary: Jelly Roll reveals he once cheated on his wife, Bunnie XO, and recalls how they got through that hurdle together.
story: Jelly Roll is getting real about the highs and lows of his relationship with his wife of nine years, Bunnie XO.
During an Oct. 21 appearance on the "Human School" podcast, the "Wild Ones" singer revealed he once cheated on his wife and had "a lot of work" to do to repair their marriage.
"I don't talk about this publicly at all but one of the worst moments of my adulthood was when I had an affair on my wife,” he said.
Jelly Roll said it marked the first time where he felt like, "I really can’t get this right at all."
"Like, I know I’m in love with this woman," he said. "It just really, really, really blew me back. And I did a lot of work to repair that relationship."
But after working on their marriage, Jelly Roll said that he and his spouse are now “stronger than we could have ever been.”
"I'm proud of who we are today," he shared. "I truly am.”
Looking back on that time in his life, Jelly Roll said he was hanging out with people who were a bad influence on him.

“I was hanging around a bunch of people that were cheating on their wives," he said. "When I was doing cocaine, I was hanging around a bunch of people that were doing cocaine. When I was drinking a lot, I was hanging around a bunch of people that were drinking a lot."
Now, Jelly Roll said he "only" wants to be around people he admires. The "Save Me" singer added that he hopes others can learn from his mistakes.

"I want men to watch this and maybe have a moment where we think as men, who are we hanging out with? And what are we talking about? What are the conversations we are having on the way home?" he said.
Jelly Roll and Bunnie XO have been married since 2016. In a 2024 TikTok video, the podcaster revealed they briefly separated in 2018 before getting back together.

"Who knew that us breaking up in 2018, me moving back to Vegas & you coming to get me back — would have put us on this wild journey called life," she wrote. "We finally committed to each other & did everything we promised each other the first night in 2016. Our castle in the sand had to crumble so we could rebuild on solid ground I yuh you so mushhh."
After Jelly Roll opened up about his infidelity, Bunnie XO responded to a social media user who criticized her decision to stay with him.

"It actually takes a stronger woman to face pain head-on, do the work, and rebuild with the man she loves — instead of running or gossiping," Bunnie XO said in an Instagram comment. "Growth isn't weakness, it's grace. But not everyone's built for that kind of strength. I pray you never have to fell that pain bc you're judging another woman's life."
Jelly Roll has two children from previous relationships, daughter Bailee Ann DeFord and son Noah “Buddy” DeFord. Both kids occasionally appear in their stepmother's videos.
In June 2024, Bunnie XO and Jelly Roll opened up about their journey with IVF as they try to have another child.

“We genuinely never thought we’d want to add to our family but something changed this year & we both just want a piece of us together to add to our already perfect family w/Bailee and Noah,” Bunnie XO said on Instagram at the time.

title: 'Love Is Blind' Creator Responds After No Couples Get Married in Season 9, a Series 1st
summary: Love Is Blind creator Chris Coelen responded after Season 9 resulted in no couples getting married, a first in Love Is Blind history.
story: With Season 9, the Netflix dating show "Love Is Blind" just reached achieved a new "first." For the first time, a season ended with no couples getting married.
In a twist that shocked many viewers, none of the couples who got engaged during the Denver-set dating experiment ended up saying "I do."
The series debuted in 2020 and has led to many long-lasting marriages and a few "Love Is Blind" babies.
The show's creator, Chris Coelen, sat down with Netflix's Tudum to share his thoughts on Season 9 and its ill-fated romances. Here's what he had to say.
What Happened in the 'Love Is Blind' Season 9 Finale?

After getting to know each other in the dating pods, six couples got engaged, but only five of them continued on with the experiment since Patrick Suzuki and Kacie McIntosh called it quits before their romantic getaway.
Out of those five couples, only three appeared in the finale.

In the season finale, Edmond Harvey and Kalybriah Haskim walked down the aisle and Edmond said "I do." However, Kalybriah wasn't prepared to commit to their relationship. Likewise, Ali Lima rejected Anton Yarosh at the altar, despite the fact that he said "I do."
Megan Walerius and Jordan Keltner never made it to their wedding since Megan called things off beforehand, citing their different lifestyles as an issue.
How 'Love Is Blind's' Creator Responded to Season 9's Outcome
Romantic weddings certainly make for entertaining TV, but dramatic breakups can create the same effect. The Season 9 "Love Is Blind" finale had neither.
Still, the show's creator didn't sweat the fact that there were no major fireworks in the finale.
“Whether they succeed or fail, the trying is the most enjoyable and important part for me,” he told Tudum.
While filming was underway, Coelen was just as interested to see all the action unfold as viewers were when they watched it at home. However, he wasn't totally surprised that no one tied the knot.

"I’m honestly surprised this is the first season where nobody got married. While we’re always rooting for our participants to find a lifelong commitment — because that’s what they all say they come to 'Love is Blind' for — most importantly, we root for them to make the decisions they feel are right for themselves. And I think that’s what happened here," he said.
As viewers make their way through this season, Coelen said he hopes they will "feel the couples ended up in the right place" and appreciate the "bravery and vulnerability of our participants."
Coelen knows people have had strong reactions to the Season 9 stars and several of the season's controversies.

"I love our fans and I love their passion, and I have strong feelings about the Denver pod squad as well. I love that over a season, my feelings (and the feelings of the fans) will evolve in different directions and that our producing team, along with so many viewers, will take away different things from watching the same scenes in the same season. It’s really fun to witness," he said.
The Show's Creator Reflected on the Show's Evolution
Even though this is the first time no one has gotten married in a "Love Is Blind" finale, Coelen said he still believes that the dating show is viable.

"I think we’ll see many happy couples continue to come out of the 'Love Is Blind' experiment in the future, who have fallen in love with who they are. We’ll also see couples decide that their love is not enough. Whatever the outcome, the journeys along the way, which reflect our society and some of the amazing people who inhabit it, will continue to be at turns joyful, frustrating, and awe-inspiring — in a word, human," he said.
Looking back on the overall success of the series, Coelen called the dating experiment “one of the most incredible things I’ve been lucky enough to be a part of, personally or professionally.”
Coelen said Season 9 is further proof that the experiment forces couples to examine what they really want in a relationship.

"In Season 9, at least one member of each couple felt their love was not strong enough to overcome the challenges of the real world, and they chose not to get married. That’s exactly how the experiment is supposed to work, so I would say not only is the experiment working, I think it’s working better than ever," he said.

title: Emma Stone Once Had a Different Stage Name. Here's What It Was
summary: Emma Stone opens up about her stage name in Hollywood and reveals the moniker she used to go by when she was younger.
story: Emma Stone says she almost chose a different stage name when she was younger.
While appearing on the Oct. 23 episode of "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert," the actor, whose real name is Emily Jean Stone, said she tried to be known as Riley when she was younger.
Stone explained in previous interviews that the name Emily Stone was "taken" at the  Screen Actors Guild, and so she needed a new name.

"I actually adopted a stage name for, I would say, like six months because the Screen Actors Guild, it’s like the Business Bureau. You can only have one person with that name,” she said. "I was 16, and I decided I wanted to be Riley for like six months. So I was Riley Stone."
Stone is credited as "Riley Stone" in the IMDb page for "Medium," which she appeared in in 2005.
Though Stone thought the moniker was "beautiful," she said she had trouble answering to that name when people would call her that on set.

“I did an episode, like a guest part, on ‘Malcolm in the Middle,’ and they kept going like, ‘Riley! Riley!’ And I had no idea who they were talking to. Truly,” she said as Colbert laughed. “And I was like, ‘I cannot be Riley.’”
“It came out of nowhere. I was just like, ‘Cool name. I’ll just be Riley.’ So I then changed it to Emma because it’s close enough to Emily,” she explained.
On “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon," Stone revealed why she chose Emma as her stage name and said it's because she adored Emma Bunton from the Spice Girls.
“So growing up I was super blonde, and my real name is Emily, but I wanted to be called Emma because of Baby Spice and guess what, now I am,” she said, laughing.

Though she goes by Emma Stone, Stone said that she likes it when people also call her by her real name. During a press conference at the 2024 Cannes Film Festival, she flashed a big smile when a reporter called her Emily.
The "Superbad" actor also told TODAY's Craig Melvin that she likes her real name and her stage name equally.
“I’m fine either way," she said of what to call her.
“I really am,” she reaffirmed. “My real name is Emily, though.”

title: Boston Rob’s No. 1 Rule for ‘Survivor’ — And How it Applies to Parenting
summary: Rob "Boston Rob" Mariano is the man in the Dunkin' costume. In an interview, he unpacks starring in the ad campaign, his reality TV career and what's next.
story: Dylan Efron may never trust Rob "Boston Rob" Mariano again.
The reality TV legend says he's "fooled" his fellow "Traitors" star, with whom he formed an alliance that sparked an off-screen friendship, three or four times this year alone.
Now, he gets to add his participation in a new ad campaign to that list.
Dunkin' and Kahlua teamed up for a new product, Kahlúa Dunkin’ Caramel Swirl Cream Liqueur, combining the flavors of Kahlúa coffee and rum with Dunkin’s caramel flavoring and cream.

For the collab, they released a high-drama, soap opera-esque commercial, starring Salma Hayek Pinault. At the end of the ad, a human-sized Dunkin' cup with a mustache is revealed as the mastermind who poured the “Kahlunkin'" treat. Who exactly was in the cup remained a mystery after the ad dropped Oct. 16.
That is, until the mascot unmasked themselves on Oct. 23.
The culprit? Everyone's favorite reality competition star, the Red Sox-hat wearing, Faithful-fooling, occasional TV villain: Boston Rob.
"I mean, Dunkin's iconic, right? I'm from Boston, so I've pretty much grown up with Dunkin' my entire life," he tells TODAY.com. (His go-to order is iced coffee, even in winter.)

The mystery stems from Boston Rob's star turn in "The Traitors" Season 3. In the first episode, Rob was introduced as a cloaked figure beneath a golden mask — the first of several dramatic reveals involving Rob, which eventually inspired his role in the new Kahlúa Dunkin’ Caramel Swirl Cream Liqueur campaign.
"It was a little bit of a play on that, where I revealed myself on 'Traitors,'" he says.
Former "Traitors" stars, like Rob's ally Ciara Miller, helped build hype for the big reveal by creating content for the official Kahlua Instagram page.
"I can't wait to see the look on their faces when they find out it's me, although I've kind of fooled Dylan (Efron) like three or four times now," he says. "The kid's never going to trust me."
Rob says he's hasn't told anyone, including his four daughters, whom he shares with wife and fellow "Survivor" alum, Amber Mariano.

In an interview with TODAY.com, Rob discusses appearing in the Dunkin' campaign with an Oscar-nominated actress, how his daughters feel about his reality TV career and what's next — including an upcoming project with a fellow "Traitors" alum set to drop "soon."
This interview has been lightly edited for clarity.
We shot it in L.A. and actually did a fitting for the cup before. It's, like, really heavy and big and everything. It's made of like, plaster.

Salma, we shot on the same day and everything. When I first showed up to set, I accidentally went into her trailer instead of mine, and there were like three dogs, camera people, makeup people, stylists. She kind of just looked over at me. I don't even know if she knew who I was, but she was like, "Honey, I think you're in the wrong place." I was like, "Yeah, you're probably right," but she was sweet. She's an icon, too, of course.
My kids. My kids are going to be excited.
They know I was doing something with Dunkin', but don't know the exact — I like to suprise them.

It's really fun. I've had a long history on reality TV. I've been doing it almost 25 years now, which is crazy. And I have a lot of friends from all the different shows over time. What was different about "Traitors" is "Traitors" brought people from outside of the competitive reality world together. So I started to get introduced to people from like the Bravo world and other shows, and that's been really cool. Dylan and I have stayed pretty good friends. But also, through social media and text, I talk to Ciara once in a while.

Never. I've never followed it. I've been out there twice now. I went for the premiere, and last week, I brought the entire family. I was only going to bring the two little ones because they were on school break, but then my older two girls were like, "We want to go, too." So the next thing you know, all six of us are going out there. It's been awesome.
I'm a terrible dancer. It would take so much work to get me out there. You know, if there's one thing I've learned over time, it's never say never.

They love it now. I mean, they're teenagers. I have teenage girls, so of course, everything I do embarrasses them. I drove them to school this morning and I was like, you know, the "Pink Pony" song (Chappell Roan's "Pink Pony Club") was on the radio, and I'm like, turning it up. They're like, "Dad!"
I love that rite of passage as a father to be able to embarrass your teenage daughters. I feel like I've earned it.
I mean, there's a lot of parallels between "Survivor," reality competition shows. I play a lot of poker, the world of business, being resilient — there's so many lessons.

Adapting to your situation, that's probably the No. 1 rule of the show. You have to figure out different ways to adapt to your situation. In life, there are challenges all the time. It's not so much what the challenges are but how you face them that makes a difference. I've found that people that are the most resilient are the ones that just don't quit.

I didn't win the first time I played. It took me four times, but I never quit. And I think a lot of those lessons I do pass on to parenting, to my kids, teaching them about being strong and being tough and just keep trying.

It's interesting, we were talking about doing another book — just recently, I had this conversation with some people on my team. I just feel like my story's not done yet. Before I write it, I want to continue the journey, because I feel like there's more and there's an evolution which is wild. This show that I went on 25 years ago to where we are now and to where we're going. I think we're going to wait a little bit to see the amendments and the next version.
I actually did shoot a project with Dylan that is going to be coming out, dropping soon. I can't tell you a lot about it, but we've already shot it. It's being edited.
It's coming soon. We're waiting for him to finish dancing I think probably, and then we're going to launch.
But a lot of fun, it kind of plays on our relationship and our competitive nature with each other.
A few years ago during the pandemic, we did watch some of the old stuff, and the kids watched it for the very first time, so that was kind of cool to share it with them.

As far as, like, where we're going, I think there's definitely an evolution. I feel like my days as a competitive reality player are kind of fulfilled, and I definitely want to move into the hosting and producing space.
I feel like that's the evolution, and that's where we're going next.

Listen, it's not because they didn't ask. I feel fulfilled with my journey on "Survivor" as a contestant. I've done everything that I wanted to do, and I have so much love and respect for that show. That's where I started, that will always be my home. That's always a part of how I got to where I am. So no shade at all.

I just feel like I've done it so many times. I have such a big target and reputation now, if I go back out there like they might let me last a little bit, but nobody's going to let me get to the end. So why not give somebody else an opportunity that needs another chance. And that's what I told Jeff way back when ... with the precursor, that if you guys absolutely tell me you need me, I will be there because they've done so much for me over the course of my life.
Nobody on that show has been a bigger winner than me. I mean, I have a wife and four kids for the last 20 years to prove it, so I'm super grateful.

title: Did Broadway Decide to Go on Strike?
summary: Will Broadway go on strike? When will Broadway go on strike? What shows will be affected? Here's why musicians might be going on strike.
story: The lights of Broadway will continue to shine after musicians reached a tentative contract agreement.

New York City’s Theater District is usually jam-packed with locals and tourists alike stepping out for a night on the town. But the musicians behind all your favorite Broadway productions were considering going on strike as soon as Oct. 23 if contract negotiations fell through.

Now that a strike has been averted, we're breaking down all that you need to know about the tentative agreement between Broadway musicians and the Broadway league and looking back on what made musicians consider a strike in the first place.
Broadway Musicians Have Reached a Tentative 3-Year Agreement
Local 802 AFM is the union that represents thousands of professional musicians in New York City, including Broadway performers.
In a press release dated Oct. 23, the union announced that it had "reached a tentative agreement" with the Broadway League, the national trade association for the Broadway industry.
The three-year agreement includes "wage increases and contribution increases to the health fund" and will now go to union members for ratification.
Local 802 President Bob Suttmann reacted to the deal in the following statement.

“United in solidarity, Local 802 Broadway musicians are thrilled to announce that we reached a tentative agreement at 4:30 am with the Broadway League that will avert a strike scheduled to begin later today. This three-year agreement provides meaningful wage and health benefit increases that will preserve crucial access to healthcare for our musicians while maintaining the strong contract protections that empower musicians to build a steady career on Broadway,” he said.
Why Was Broadway Considering Going on Strike?

On Oct. 21, Local 802 AFM posted an update on its website announcing Broadway musicians' "intent to 'strike immediately'" if their efforts to obtain a new contract are not achieved by the morning of Thursday, Oct. 23.
In a statement, Suttmann offered the following thoughts on the looming strike.

“The Broadway musicians represented by Local 802 AFM are going into mediation on Wednesday, Oct. 22. If we do not have a new contract by Thursday morning, we are prepared to strike immediately. We are hopeful that we can reach an agreement,” he said.
The last major Broadway strike occurred in 2007 and was prompted by the stagehand union. The strike lasted 19 days.
According to AFM Local 802, members of the union have been working without a contract since Aug. 31, 2025.
On Oct. 13, the union announced that Broadway members "overwhelmingly voted to authorize a strike if needed." More specifically, 98% of members voted for a strike if their requests are not met.
The union is seeking several improvements to its prior contract, including the following:
Fair wagesStable health coverage Employment and income security (ie. not eliminating current Broadway jobs)
Fair wages
Stable health coverage
Employment and income security (ie. not eliminating current Broadway jobs)
On Oct. 1, the musicians sent a letter with their requests to the Broadway League. It was signed by nearly all 1,200 Broadway musicians.
The union said the Broadway League "continues to demand unacceptable wages and reduced jobs and benefits in the current contract talks."
Suttmann elaborated on the fears many union members have in a statement.

“On the heels of the most successful season(s) in history, the Broadway League wants the working musicians and artists who fueled that very success to accept wage cuts, threats to healthcare benefits, and potential job losses. Faced with such an egregious erosion of their working conditions, Local 802 Broadway musicians and other artists are ready to leverage every ounce of their collective power, up to and including a strike. Committing to anything less would mean sacrificing far too many hard-won gains,” he said.

The Broadway League reacted to contract negotiations in the following statement, shared with TODAY: "Good-faith negotiations happen at the bargaining table, not in the press. We value our musicians and we are committed to working in good faith to get a fair contract done."
What Shows Would Have Been Affected?
If Broadway musicians did go on strike on Thursday, Oct. 23, many musicals would have been affected. AFM Local 802 shared a list on its website of the shows and the theaters.
